lexicon_requests.reason: Intensive beatitude formula - semantic range and construction differences from בָּרוּךְ
Specific wicked category - etymology and distinction from רְשָׁעִים/חַטָּאִים
Sitting/dwelling terminology - cultic and social dimensions
Delight/desire - erotic vs. dutiful connotations in Torah context
Meditation practice - vocal vs. silent, technical vs. casual study
Transplanting vs. planting - cultivation implications for righteousness
Irrigation channels vs. natural streams - agricultural precision
Chaff - agricultural waste product and judgment metaphor
Standing in judgment - judicial and resurrection implications
Assembly terminology - cultic vs. eschatological gathering
Divine knowing - cognitive vs. covenantal/intimate knowledge
Perishing - active destruction vs. natural decay

concordance_requests.purpose: Track beatitude formulas introducing ideal figures
Divine Torah references and their contexts
Merismus patterns for totality and continuity

figurative_requests.reason: Path/way imagery for moral choices - physical movement as spiritual trajectory | Vehicle: walking | Related terms: walk, walks, walked, standing, stand, stands, stood, sitting, sit, sits, sat
Torah as object of desire - erotic/passionate language for religious devotion | Vehicle: delight | Related terms: desire, desires, longing, pleasure, pleasures, cherish, cherishes
Transplanted tree by streams - agricultural cultivation metaphor for spiritual growth | Vehicle: transplanted | Related terms: transplant, transplants, planted, planting, cultivated, cultivating
Irrigation channels - engineered water systems for sustained spiritual nourishment | Vehicle: channels | Related terms: channel, streams, stream, watercourses, irrigation, canals
Chaff scattered by wind - agricultural waste as metaphor for worthless existence | Vehicle: chaff | Related terms: chaff, husks, waste, refuse, stubble
Wind driving/scattering - natural force as agent of divine judgment | Vehicle: drives | Related terms: drive, driving, scatter, scatters, scattering, blow, blows, disperses
Standing in judgment - judicial imagery for eschatological vindication | Vehicle: stand | Related terms: standing, stands, stood, arise, arises, arising

commentary_requests.reason: Opening beatitude formula - how commentators interpret אַשְׁרֵי and the threefold wicked categories
Torah meditation as delight - traditional understanding of חֵפֶץ and יֶהְגֶּה practices
Transplanted tree metaphor - classical interpretation of שָׁתוּל and cultivation imagery
Chaff imagery brevity - how commentators explain minimal description of wicked
Judicial assembly language - traditional eschatology of מִשְׁפָּט and עֲדַת צַדִּיקִים
Two ways conclusion - how commentators frame יוֹדֵעַ יְהוָה and divine knowledge vs. perishing

macro_questions: What specific practices does 'meditating on Torah day and night' (הגה) refer to in post-exilic Jewish communities?
How does the legal/judicial imagery in vv. 5-6 (משפט, עדת צדיקים) relate to eschatological judgment traditions?
What are the Ancient Near Eastern parallels to the 'two ways' theology presented here?
How does the tree imagery connect to broader biblical and ANE traditions of cosmic trees and divine blessing?
What is the significance of the threefold progression in v. 1 (counsel→path→seat) in Hebrew wisdom literature?
How does this psalm's retribution theology set up tensions that later psalms will explore (particularly in lament traditions)?
What is the relationship between individual piety and community identity in the 'assembly of the righteous' concept?
How does the divine 'knowing' in v. 6 relate to covenant election and divine care traditions?
micro_questions: Why does the psalm use שָׁתוּל (transplanted) rather than נָטַע (planted) - does this suggest conversion rather than natural righteousness?
What is the significance of יֶהְגֶּה (murmur/mutter) - does Torah study involve specific vocal practices?
Why is the description of the wicked so abbreviated compared to the elaborate righteous imagery?
How does the judicial language in v.5 (משפט, עדת) relate to the agricultural metaphors of vv.3-4?
Why does YHWH actively 'know' the righteous way but the wicked way simply 'perishes' without divine action?
What distinguishes the three categories of wicked people in v.1 (רשעים, חטאים, לצים)?
How does the merismus 'day and night' in v.2 relate to the seasonal imagery 'in its season' in v.3?
